0: Media playback is unsupported on your device Media caption Lightning strikes parts of UK NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Thunderstorms and torrential rain have swept across parts of southern Britain, with lightning flashing across the sky. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Around 15,000 lightning strikes were recorded in four hours on Saturday night, BBC Weather said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Stansted Airport reported delays to flights on Sunday morning after a lightning strike briefly left its aircraft fuelling system "unavailable". NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Met Office has issued a yellow warning for heavy rain and flooding across Wales and most of England. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A house in Stanway, Essex, lost its roof to a fire after lightning struck it in the early hours of Sunday morning. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Firefighters worked on the blaze for almost three hours, eventually extinguishing it at 04:30 BST. No injuries were reported in the incident. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image caption Firefighters arrived at a house in Essex to find the whole of the roof alight NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Later in the morning, storms brought more than an inch of rain to parts of Wales and the Midlands in just an hour. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Parts of Wales and central and southern England could see further thunderstorms on both Sunday and bank holiday Monday, with the Met Office warning of the possibility of power cuts and delays to trains and buses. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image copyright Reuters Image caption The Met Office has warned of flooding and possible damage to buildings from lightning, which is pictured here striking over the city of London NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image copyright PA/TowerRNLI Image caption Bolts of lightning flash across the sky over the River Thames in this photo taken by the RNLI late on Saturday night NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image copyright Ems - Hayling Island/@auntymems Image caption A dramatic and purple sky was photographed over Hayling Island, off the south coast of England near Portsmouth, as thunderstorms moved northwards across the mainland NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Many people got out their cameras to photograph and video Saturday night's electrical storm, which was called "utterly insane" and "like being under a strobe light". NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Others remarked that they had "never seen a storm quite like this" and said the flashes were "stunning". NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image copyright Andrew Lanxon Hoyle/@Batteryhq Image caption Bolts light up the sky over the the Suleymaniye Mosque in Dalston, east London NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image copyright Jason Arthur Image caption Jason Arthur took this picture in Gravesend, Kent NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image copyright Roy McDonald Image caption Lightning turns the sky purple over Leighton Buzzard NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR BBC Weather presenter Tomasz Schafernaker called it the "mother of all thunderstorms" as he watched it over London. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I've never seen a storm with such frequent lightning in my life I don't think. Mostly sheet lightning and not too loud but flashes are spectacular," he said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image copyright Ben Hensel Image caption West Wellow, Hampshire, was the stage for this impressive photograph by Ben Hensel NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image copyright Yulia Emelianenko Image caption Yulia Emelianenko captured the scene above Canary Wharf in London NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image copyright Paul Greenford tyres/@Atko80 Image caption Paul Greenford was in a caravan at a campsite in Henley-on-Thames when the heavy rain and lightning storm struck NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image copyright Harry Neary/@grumpyrocker Image caption Harry Neary, who began setting up his camera once he noticed the lightning flashes, photographed bolts near the village of Broadwindsor in Dorset NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Forecaster Gemma Plumb, from BBC Weather, said that as the storms pushed northwards across England on Sunday, more would be coming up over the English Channel from the continent. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Met Office weather warning for rain is in force until 06:00 on Monday and covers all of Wales as well as southern and central England. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Flooding of homes and businesses could happen quickly, the Met Office said. It added that fast-flowing or deep floodwater was possible with damage to some buildings from flooding, lightning strikes, hail or strong winds. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR It comes after a warm Saturday, with a top temperature of 27.3C in Hurn, Dorset. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image copyright @samueltwilkinson/PA Image caption A long strike of lightning dwarfs London's Shard, which stands at 310m NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image copyright Reuters Image caption Lightning strikes above Wembley Stadium in London on Saturday night, where Fulham beat Aston Villa in the Championship play-off final earlier in the day NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image copyright Karl McCarthy/@McCarthyKarl Image caption The cloudy sky was lit up in purple as lightning struck above Tredegar in south Wales NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image copyright J/@dxtjxsh Image caption Hundreds of people in London took out their cameras to snap the lightning storm, including in Plaistow, in the east of the capital caption copyright It rain NEWLINE_CHAR of Hensel cameras lightning, the find under Hampshire, from and
